channel.title: Laptop CPU temp
channel.description:
So the fan of my laptop was rattling during boot and a few minutes afterwards, after which the noise always stops. So I opened it up and took the fan out. First thing I did was use compressed air to clean the air outlet, which was completely filled with dust. And I really mean completely, no air could get out. Put the fan back in, and it doesn't rattle that loud anymore. Next thing was a stress test with AIDA64. The core temperature jumped to 71C in a few seconds, but stayed there. The fan reached 3500RPM.
After stopping the stress test, the core temperature dropped to about 47C. 20 minutes later, it's around 45C, and the fan is doing 2300 RPM.
Like I said, the noise has dropped but it's still there. Does this mean that the fan is fucked and I need a new one, or can I leave it like this.
While I was at it, I also cleaned my desktop. I can scratch the thermal paste off of the heatsink, does this mean I need to put new paste on it? I've never put new paste on it, and the desktop is about 5 years old.

item.title: Laptop CPU temp
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:14, topic:377417”][quote author=jmood128 link=topic=473312.msg3495655#msg3495655 date=1297297699]
For some reason I run my laptop 24 hours a day and it has never gotten above 60C. I suggest you just buy a new one.
[/quote]

That’s a ridiculous suggestion. Some computers are made to run hotter than others, also just because a computer is running a little on the hot side doesn’t mean it needs replaced. Even if you couldn’t/didn’t want to fix the issue, there would be no need to get another one until the original actually stops working.[/quote]

Haha, you’re right. Why the fuck would I buy a new laptop, when it’s only running a tad bit hot. I’ll buy a new one when I’m either unhappy with it’s performance, or when it costs me more to fix it than to replace it.

Oh, and I already fixed it. A €24,- fan did the job.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop CPU temp

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

jmood128:

For some reason I run my laptop 24 hours a day and it has never gotten above 60C. I suggest you just buy a new one.

That’s a ridiculous suggestion. Some computers are made to run hotter than others, also just because a computer is running a little on the hot side doesn’t mean it needs replaced. Even if you couldn’t/didn’t want to fix the issue, there would be no need to get another one until the original actually stops working.

item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

Meh, my old dell laptop (L400) has been grinding the fan for the last 6 years. Idles at about 60 degrees, but still works mint. But anyway, I went and got myself an eM350 a few months ago and put the dell into permanent storage in my closet as a backup.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop CPU temp
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

bootnecklad:

Hows the noise/airflow/temperature now?

The noise is fine now, I can still hear the fan but it’s the same as it was when I bought it. I did another stress test, and it reached temperatures of around 66C, so that’s fine too I guess. The only think that I find odd is that during the stress test the fan sometimes dropped to 100RPM, according to AIDA64. I didn’t hear it spinning down though, so I doubt it actually dropped to 100RPM.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop CPU temp
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

So what am I looking for when buying a new fan? Is there anything bad that can happen when I buy the wrong fan? I mean, I’ll notice it when it won’t start spinning as soon as I boot my laptop, so I doubt it will fry my CPU.

eetnordic.com has the one I guess I need in stock, but they charge €13,50 for delivery. It’s this one: http://uk.eetnordic.com/product.aspx?id=7415970000&path=Packard-Bell-Ajax-CPU-FAN

Edit:
Ordered a fan yesterday, and it got delivered today. It’s working fine now.

Read full topic

A fan in my desktop is making death noises too, but the sound is too slow to be the CPU fan, so I’m good there. But I have about 5ish fans in there so I haven’t tried to find the bad one yet.

Anyway, I think those temperatures sound normal.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop CPU temp
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Mopman:

Did you blow out the fan? That’s the noise fan bearings like to make if they’re on their way out, and I’ve had fan speeds misrepresent as higher then too (cuz the fan slips)

Yea, I used our compressor to clean the fan itself, and the air outlet. The outlet itself was completely closed with dust. I guess it’s time for a new fan then?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:

Did you blow out the fan? That’s the noise fan bearings like to make if they’re on their way out, and I’ve had fan speeds misrepresent as higher then too (cuz the fan slips)

item.title: Laptop CPU temp
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:377417”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=473312.msg3461209#msg3461209 date=1294499153]
While I was at it, I also cleaned my desktop. I can scratch the thermal paste off of the heatsink, does this mean I need to put new paste on it? I’ve never put new paste on it, and the desktop is about 5 years old.
[/quote]
To be fair, you could scratch the thermal paste off but then you’ll get 99999 temps, so basically if you have taken some off, take it all and reapply it.

@laptop
Are you sure that the heatsink and fan and secured to the cpu tightly and flat. You need to get perfect contact between the two or else you will get wtf temps. 45C is respectable for a laptop but the fan speed is a bit too fast so try and secure it and see what happens.[/quote]

I’ve reapplied the paste, so that’s solved. Was annoying as fuck though, it’s quite a tiny case and I’ve put in an extra HDD, which wasn’t even possible after I removed the heatsink. Finally had the heatsink back in, when I found out that I forgot to put that piece of metal around the cpu.

Laptop:
I’m not that worried about the temperature now. After some googling I found out that the idle temperature is normal, and the stress test temperature is only a degree or 2 too high. But it’s the noise that bothers me. I can’t really describe the noise. It’s a bit like the noise a HDD makes during access, but louder. CPU is now at 46C (cores are both 50C) and the fan is doing 2100RPM.

Read full topic

item.title: Laptop CPU temp
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

While I was at it, I also cleaned my desktop. I can scratch the thermal paste off of the heatsink, does this mean I need to put new paste on it? I’ve never put new paste on it, and the desktop is about 5 years old.

To be fair, you could scratch the thermal paste off but then you’ll get 99999 temps, so basically if you have taken some off, take it all and reapply it.

@laptop
Are you sure that the heatsink and fan and secured to the cpu tightly and flat. You need to get perfect contact between the two or else you will get wtf temps. 45C is respectable for a laptop but the fan speed is a bit too fast so try and secure it and see what happens.

Read full topic
